Yes, the object is output, but the result custom format is three blank lines.

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
start-job { echo hi | select-string hi } | receive-job -wait -auto
```

# Expected behavior

```none

hi

```

# Actual behavior

```none



```

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
The problem is that the formatting data associated with instance of type `Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.MatchInfo`  is apparently incorrectly applied to the _deserialized_ instances (`Deserialized.Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.MatchInfo`) that are returned from the background job.

The bug still exists in PowerShell Core 7.0.0-preview.5 and is also in Windows PowerShell 5.1

The data is there, however, so a suboptimal workaround (that won't give you the same formatting) is to pipe to `-Format-Table`, for instance, or to extract the `.Line` property.

comments.author: jszabo98
comments.body:
For contrast, start-threadjob in PS 6 works fine, since it doesn't serialize:
```powershell
start-threadjob { echo hi | select-string hi } | receive-job -wait -auto
```
Although in PS 7 preview 6 I get this error:
```
Select-String: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
```

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body: Thanks, @jszabo98 - that's a separate problem, though, not directly related to formatting data (though it does seem to be related to the VT sequences used to highlight the matching part of the line); I've created #11242.

title: select-string outputs invisibly in jobs (or invoke-command)
